source: Laws of UX by Jon Yablonski

laws.name: Fitts's Law
laws.description: The time to acquire a target is a function of the distance to and size of the target. Make important targets large and position them close to users.

checks.name: Touch target size
checks.description: Interactive elements should be at least 44x44px for touch devices

checks.name: Touch target spacing
checks.description: Interactive elements should have adequate spacing to prevent mis-taps

checks.name: CTA prominence
checks.description: Primary call-to-action buttons should be larger and more prominent than secondary actions

checks.name: Small icon buttons
checks.description: Icon-only buttons with minimal text may be too small for easy interaction

laws.name: Hick's Law
laws.description: The time it takes to make a decision increases with the number and complexity of choices. Minimize choices when response times are critical.

checks.name: Navigation item count
checks.description: Primary navigation should have 7 or fewer items

checks.name: Action button count
checks.description: Screens should limit visible action buttons to reduce decision fatigue

checks.name: Dropdown option count
checks.description: Dropdowns with many options should include search or grouping

checks.name: Excessive navigation
checks.description: Navigation with too many items creates cognitive overload

laws.name: Miller's Law
laws.description: The average person can only keep 7 (plus or minus 2) items in their working memory. Chunk content into digestible groups.

checks.name: Form field count
checks.description: Forms should have 9 or fewer visible fields without grouping

checks.name: Items per section
checks.description: Each section or group should contain 7 or fewer items

checks.name: Tab count
checks.description: Tab interfaces should have 5 or fewer tabs visible at once

checks.name: Extreme form complexity
checks.description: Forms with 15+ fields require chunking into multi-step flows

laws.name: Law of Proximity
laws.description: Objects that are near, or proximate to each other, tend to be grouped together. Use proximity to create relationships between elements.

checks.name: Label-input proximity
checks.description: Form labels should be close to their associated inputs

checks.name: Action button grouping
checks.description: Related action buttons should be grouped together

laws.name: Doherty Threshold
laws.description: Productivity soars when a computer and its users interact at a pace (<400ms) that ensures neither has to wait on the other.

checks.name: Immediate feedback
checks.description: User actions should provide immediate visual feedback

laws.name: Jakob's Law
laws.description: Users spend most of their time on other sites. This means that users prefer your site to work the same way as all the other sites they already know.

checks.name: Follow conventions
checks.description: UI patterns should follow established conventions

laws.name: Aesthetic-Usability Effect
laws.description: Users often perceive aesthetically pleasing design as design that's more usable. Aesthetic design creates a positive response and increases tolerance for usability issues.

checks.name: Visual balance
checks.description: Layout should have appropriate whitespace and visual balance

laws.name: Peak-End Rule
laws.description: People judge an experience largely based on how they felt at its peak and at its end, rather than based on the sum of every moment of the experience.

checks.name: Success states
checks.description: Key moments (completion, success) should have satisfying feedback
